articles.headline: Guilty Plea in Fraud by Adviser to Stars
articles.snippet: The adviser, Kenneth I. Starr, admitting that he cheated wealthy and elderly clients out of tens of millions of dollars.
articles.abstract: The adviser, Kenneth I. Starr, admitting that he cheated wealthy and elderly clients out of tens of millions of dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kenneth I. Starr, the New York investment adviser who once counted Hollywood celebrities like Al Pacino, Martin Scorsese and Sylvester Stallone as clients, pleaded guilty on Friday in Federal District Court in Manhattan to charges that he diverted tens of millions of dollars of his clients’ money to pay for his lavish lifestyle.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Colin Moynihan

articles.headline: Back-to-School Shoppers Focus on Necessities
articles.snippet: Many families have trimmed their back-to-school budgets, dealing an unexpected blow to retailers.
articles.abstract: Many families have trimmed their back-to-school budgets, dealing an unexpected blow to retailers.
articles.lead_paragraph: QUEENSBURY, N.Y.  It was the day before Libbie Palmer began school, and her mother, Becky, was taking her shopping for one last thing at the Aviation Mall here in the Adirondack foothills. “I realized I didn’t get her a pair of shoes,” Ms. Palmer said.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Malia Wollan

articles.headline: In Using Software to Write a Will, a Lawyer Is Still Helpful
articles.snippet: Four wills, written using four different computer programs, point up some strengths and some surprising weaknesses.
articles.abstract: Four wills, written using four different computer programs, point up some strengths and some surprising weaknesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: I drafted my will four times this week  not because I was obsessed with the macabre, but because I wanted to test how computer-generated wills would fare under human scrutiny.

articles.headline: Obama Tries to Calm Religious Tensions
articles.snippet: President Obama gave a call for better relations between Muslims and non-Muslims at home and abroad, defending the “inalienable rights” of those who worship Islam.
articles.abstract: President Obama gave a call for better relations between Muslims and non-Muslims at home and abroad, defending the “inalienable rights” of those who worship Islam.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama gave an impassioned call on Friday for tolerance and better relations between Muslims and non-Muslims at home and abroad, defending the “inalienable rights” of those who practice Islam to do so freely.

articles.headline: Tax Cuts May Prove Better for Politicians Than for Economy
articles.snippet: The Congressional Budget Office found that extending the Bush tax cuts would be the least effective way to reduce unemployment. But the White House largely favors the cuts.
articles.abstract: The Congressional Budget Office found that extending the Bush tax cuts would be the least effective way to reduce unemployment. But the White House largely favors the cuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: With Congressional midterm elections looming, the financial debate in Washington this fall will probably be consumed by one incendiary and expensive issue: whether, and how, to extend the multitrillion-dollar Bush tax cuts.

articles.headline: H.P.’s Blundering Board
articles.snippet: When Hewlett-Packard’s board ousted its chief executive, Mark V. Hurd, it neglected to make a legally binding deal to keep him from jumping to a rival.
articles.abstract: When Hewlett-Packard’s board ousted its chief executive, Mark V. Hurd, it neglected to make a legally binding deal to keep him from jumping to a rival.
articles.lead_paragraph: There they go again.

articles.headline: German Identity, Long Dormant, Reasserts Itself
articles.snippet: A more confident nation has asserted itself in foreign policy, despite economic troubles and some internal dissent.
articles.abstract: A more confident nation has asserted itself in foreign policy, despite economic troubles and some internal dissent.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN  As a youth in the 1950s, the film director Volker Schlöndorff tried to hide his German origins by learning to speak unaccented French. This summer, his daughter painted German flags on her cheeks and joined crowds of thousands on the Kurfürstendamm, a historic avenue, waving their black, red and gold banners to celebrate the country’s World Cup victories.

articles.headline: City Disavows Pastor’s Talk of Burning Koran
articles.snippet: Terry Jones’s actions have dragged Gainesville, Fla., into infamy, and residents, aghast, are taking it personally.
articles.abstract: Terry Jones’s actions have dragged Gainesville, Fla., into infamy, and residents, aghast, are taking it personally.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAINESVILLE, Fla.  Stephanie George used to see members of the Dove World Outreach Center at her neighborhood grocery store, wearing T-shirts that said “Islam is of the devil.” But on Friday, she and her friend Lynda Dillon showed up early at Dragonfly Graphics to order a dozen shirts with a different message: “Love, not Dove.”

articles.headline: Vacancies Strain White House’s Goals for Economy
articles.snippet: A half-dozen appointed posts with vast powers over the economy remain unfilled even as President Obama signaled that he was close to choosing a director for a new consumer bureau.
articles.abstract: A half-dozen appointed posts with vast powers over the economy remain unfilled even as President Obama signaled that he was close to choosing a director for a new consumer bureau.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama signaled on Friday that he was close to choosing a director for a new consumer bureau, but an array of top jobs that will be crucial to shaping economic policy and financial regulation for the rest of his term remain unfilled.

articles.headline: Global Rules for Banks Draw Near
articles.snippet: Regulators hope to end their meetings in Basel, Switzerland, with new rules to prevent financial crises.
articles.abstract: Regulators hope to end their meetings in Basel, Switzerland, with new rules to prevent financial crises.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT  If all goes well, the world will be a slightly safer place after top central bankers and bank regulators emerge Sunday from meetings in Basel, Switzerland.

articles.headline: A G.O.P. Leader Tightly Bound to Lobbyists
articles.snippet: As Democrats try to cast John A. Boehner of Ohio, the House minority leader, as the face of the Republican Party, his ties to lobbyists are under attack.
articles.abstract: As Democrats try to cast John A. Boehner of Ohio, the House minority leader, as the face of the Republican Party, his ties to lobbyists are under attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  House Democrats were preparing late last year for the first floor vote on the financial regulatory overhaul when Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio and other Republican leaders summoned more than 100 industry lobbyists and conservative political activists to Capitol Hill for a private strategy session.

articles.headline: The Loneliest Analyst
articles.snippet: When a Florida bank sued the analyst Richard X. Bove for his critique of its financial health, his colleagues and his employer abandoned him.
articles.abstract: When a Florida bank sued the analyst Richard X. Bove for his critique of its financial health, his colleagues and his employer abandoned him.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lutz, Fla.
articles.byline: By Andrew Martin and Louise Story

articles.headline: Housing Doesn’t Need a Crash. It Needs Bold Ideas.
articles.snippet: Unfortunately, it has taken the ugly specter of a free fall or deep freeze in many real estate markets to get people talking about bolder alternatives.
articles.abstract: Unfortunately, it has taken the ugly specter of a free fall or deep freeze in many real estate markets to get people talking about bolder alternatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: WE all know that most of us don’t tackle problems until they’ve morphed into full-blown crises. Think of all those intersections that get stop signs only after a bunch of accidents have occurred.

articles.headline: Resale Fees That Only Developers Could Love
articles.snippet: An increasingly common fee allows developers to collect 1 percent of the sales price from the seller every time the property changes hands for the next 99 years.
articles.abstract: An increasingly common fee allows developers to collect 1 percent of the sales price from the seller every time the property changes hands for the next 99 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: REBECCA AND TRENT DUPAIX of Eagle Mountain, Utah, spent a year searching for their dream home. The couple, who have five children, considered 15 to 20 houses before finding “the one.”

articles.headline: Watching the Catwalk, and Clicking ‘Add to Cart’
articles.snippet: At this year’s Fashion Week, all shoppers can watch shows online and, in some cases, order what they see.
articles.abstract: At this year’s Fashion Week, all shoppers can watch shows online and, in some cases, order what they see.
articles.lead_paragraph: It used to be that designers showed clothes at Fashion Week to court the influential few, mainly the buyers and fashion editors who determined what styles would be hot in retail stores a season away.

articles.headline: Security in Afghanistan Is Deteriorating, Aid Groups Say
articles.snippet: Worsening security in Afghanistan has raised serious concerns about whether it can hold legitimate elections for Parliament next Saturday.
articles.abstract: Worsening security in Afghanistan has raised serious concerns about whether it can hold legitimate elections for Parliament next Saturday.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Even as more American troops flow into the country, Afghanistan is more dangerous than it has ever been during this war, with security deteriorating in recent months, according to international organizations and humanitarian groups.

articles.headline: Russia Uses Microsoft to Suppress Dissent
articles.snippet: One of the authorities’ new tactics for quelling dissent in Russia is confiscating computers under the pretext of searching for pirated Microsoft software.
articles.abstract: One of the authorities’ new tactics for quelling dissent in Russia is confiscating computers under the pretext of searching for pirated Microsoft software.
articles.lead_paragraph: IRKUTSK, Russia — It was late one afternoon in January when a squad of plainclothes police officers arrived at the headquarters of a prominent environmental group here. They brushed past the staff with barely a word and instead set upon the computers before carting them away. Taken were files that chronicled a generation’s worth of efforts to protect the Siberian wilderness.

articles.headline: House G.O.P. Leader Signals He’s Open to Obama Tax Cut
articles.snippet: The House Republican leader, John A. Boehner, made clear that he supports continuing lower rates for all, but would vote in favor letting the tax cuts expire for the wealthy if Democrats insisted.
articles.abstract: The House Republican leader, John A. Boehner, made clear that he supports continuing lower rates for all, but would vote in favor letting the tax cuts expire for the wealthy if Democrats insisted.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The House Republican leader, John A. Boehner, on Sunday opened the door to a compromise on the contentious issue of the Bush-era tax cuts, saying he would vote to maintain lower rates for families earning less than $250,000 even if President Obama and Democrats insisted on ending the cuts for wealthier Americans.

articles.headline: Regulators Back New Bank Rules to Avert Crises
articles.snippet: New rules are designed to avert future financial disasters, but they could also dampen bank profits.
articles.abstract: New rules are designed to avert future financial disasters, but they could also dampen bank profits.
articles.lead_paragraph: BASEL, Switzerland  The world’s top bank regulators agreed Sunday on far-reaching new rules intended to make the global banking industry safer and protect international economies from future financial disasters.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Sewell Chan

articles.headline: F.C.C. Likely to Open New Airwaves to Wireless
articles.snippet: Allowing anyone to use “white spaces” in the spectrum would open the door to supercharged Wi-Fi networks.
articles.abstract: Allowing anyone to use “white spaces” in the spectrum would open the door to supercharged Wi-Fi networks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When the Federal Communications Commission first approved the use of unlicensed bands of the airwaves decades ago, it began a revolution in consumer electronics  first in television remote controls and garage door openers, then in baby monitors and cordless phones, and most recently in wireless computer networks.

articles.headline: At Goldman, Partners Are Made, and Unmade
articles.snippet: Becoming a partner at Goldman Sachs is thought of as equal to winning the lottery, but it can be taken away.
articles.abstract: Becoming a partner at Goldman Sachs is thought of as equal to winning the lottery, but it can be taken away.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, becoming a partner at Goldman Sachs is considered the equivalent of winning the lottery.

articles.headline: Retooling in Response to Politico
articles.snippet: In October, Nationaljournal.com will begin offering content from The National Journal, Congress Daily and Hotline on a free site in a bid to fend off online competitors.
articles.abstract: In October, Nationaljournal.com will begin offering content from The National Journal, Congress Daily and Hotline on a free site in a bid to fend off online competitors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Everyone knows that Washington is a pretty good place to look for news. Less well known? You can make money doing it.

articles.headline: Chinese Remake the ‘Made in Italy’ Fashion Label
articles.snippet: Prato, an Italian textile center, is now home to about 3,000 businesses run by Chinese, stoking resentment.
articles.abstract: Prato, an Italian textile center, is now home to about 3,000 businesses run by Chinese, stoking resentment.
articles.lead_paragraph: PRATO, Italy  Over the years, Italy learned the difficult lesson that it could no longer compete with China on price. And so, its business class dreamed, Italy would sell quality, not quantity. For centuries, this walled medieval city just outside of Florence has produced some of the world’s finest fabrics, becoming a powerhouse for “Made in Italy” chic.

articles.headline: Retiring Later Is Hard Road for Laborers
articles.snippet: A report found one in three older workers has a physically demanding job, complicating a Social Security overhaul.
articles.abstract: A report found one in three older workers has a physically demanding job, complicating a Social Security overhaul.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the Cooper Tire plant in Findlay, Ohio, Jack Hartley, who is 58, works a 12-hour shift assembling tires: pulling piles of rubber and lining over a drum, cutting the material with a hot knife, lifting the half-finished tire, which weighs 10 to 20 pounds, and throwing it onto a rack.

articles.headline: Fastest Net Service in U.S. Coming to Chattanooga
articles.snippet: The service will put a midsize Southern city among the world leaders in digital technology, but the speed will be expensive.
articles.abstract: The service will put a midsize Southern city among the world leaders in digital technology, but the speed will be expensive.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the global race to see who can offer the fastest Internet service, an unlikely challenger has emerged: Chattanooga, Tenn.

articles.headline: Search Takes a Social Turn
articles.snippet: Sites are trying to make search more helpful by showing what your friends — or other people like you — like.
articles.abstract: Sites are trying to make search more helpful by showing what your friends — or other people like you — like.
articles.lead_paragraph: Now, even on the Internet, it is not what you know but who you know.

articles.headline: Hollywood Reporter to Become a Weekly Magazine
articles.snippet: Driven to the fringes by blog competitors, the five-times-a-week publication is being remade as a glossy, large-format weekly magazine.
articles.abstract: Driven to the fringes by blog competitors, the five-times-a-week publication is being remade as a glossy, large-format weekly magazine.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  The Hollywood Reporter has been dying a slow death for a decade, bleeding from layoffs, vanishing advertisers and diminished relevance in a news cycle now dominated by cutthroat entertainment blogs.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: A Tech World That Centers on the User
articles.snippet: The consumer is now the center of the entertainment and information universe, Nick Bilton writes in the book “I Live in the Future & Here’s How It Works.”
articles.abstract: The consumer is now the center of the entertainment and information universe, Nick Bilton writes in the book “I Live in the Future & Here’s How It Works.”
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was adapted from the book “I Live in the Future & Here’s How It Works” by Nick Bilton, the lead writer for The New York Times technology blog Bits. The book, to be published on Tuesday by Crown Business, examines the impact of technology on our lives.
